awd_titl_txt: CCRI: MEDIUM: Collaborative Research: F1/10 RACECAR: Community Platforms for Safe, Secure and Coordinated Autonomy
awd_abstract_narration:
F1/10 is a shared, open-sourced infrastructure for the development and validation of new approaches to autonomous perception, planning, control and coordination. This community platform will facilitate autonomous system research, education and bench-marking through the creation of a new class of high-performance autonomous racing cars, that are 1/10th the size of a real (Formula 1) car and can reach a top speed of 50mph. The goal is to enable a wide range of experimental research and education in Safe, Secure, Coordinated and Efficient Autonomy. Much of today's research on Autonomous vehicles (AVs) is limited to experimentation on expensive commercial vehicles that require large teams with diverse skills and power-hungry platforms. Testing the limits of safety and performance on such vehicles is costly and hazardous. It is also outside the reach of most academic departments and research groups. Furthermore, little research has been devoted to the development of safety benchmarks and infrastructure for certifying autonomous systems, guaranteeing the safety of data-driven decision making, power-efficient perception and control for efficient autonomy, active coordinated safety for large vehicle fleets, and cyber-physical security of autonomous vehicles. All of these are fundamental requirements on the road to achieving the social benefits of autonomous vehicles, and autonomous systems more generally. F1/10 provides rapid prototyping hardware, software and algorithmic platforms, with full documentation and community support for research and development of future autonomous systems. 

Autonomous vehicles are emerging as integral components of the US economy, and in the future, they may be at the heart of the national economy's competitiveness in transportation and logistics. Enabling such a transformation requires building reliably safe and efficient autonomous vehicles and the contributions of a very diverse community of researchers from engineering, human factors and computer science. The project's intellectual merit resides in the design and deployment of scaled autonomous cars that are affordable, safe to experiment with, easy to customize, can be shared widely, and that can support a wide range of necessary research in autonomous vehicles. This project's broader goal is to stimulate and accelerate cross-disciplinary research in autonomous vehicle safety and efficiency, at a time when such work is urgently needed. This project will enable researchers in autonomous hardware, safety, security, and traffic to produce high-confidence autonomous systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
F1/10 is a shared, open-sourced scaled infrastructure for the development and validation of new approaches to perception, planning, control and coordination with scaled Connected Autonomous Vehicle (CAV) systems. The goal is to enable a wide range of experimental research, education and benchmarking in Safe, Secure, Coordinated and Efficient Autonomy.

Much of today's CAV research relies on experimentation with expensive full-scale commercial vehicles that require large teams with diverse skills and power-hungry platforms. Testing the limits of safety and performance on such full-scale vehicles is costly and hazardous. It is also outside the reach of most academic departments and research groups. Furthermore, little research has been devoted to the development of safety benchmarks and infrastructure for certifying autonomous vehicle systems, guaranteeing the safety of data-driven decision making, power-efficient perception and control for efficient autonomy, active coordinated safety for vehicle fleets, and cyber-physical security of autonomous vehicles. All of these are fundamental requirements on the path to realizing the societal benefits of connected autonomous vehicles.

Hence, the goals of this project were to develop tools and the human resource base to conceive, investigate, implement and validate with scaled Connected Autonomous Vehicle (CAV) systems. To this end, F1/10 provides rapid prototyping hardware and software frameworks, with full documentation and community support, to empower research and development of future connected autonomous vehicle systems. We pursued a multi-pronged approach for developing: (1) Open-source 1/10-scale autonomous vehicles; (2) Autonomous driving simulators, supporting multiple scaled cars, environments, and configurations; (3) Comprehensive reference documentation; (4) Training material, including a class-tested set of lectures and coding labs to support autonomous driving pedagogy; and (5) Outreach in the form of Workshops/Tutorials/Competitions both locally (in middle- and high-schools, university) as well as nationally/internationally (in conferences).

These activities were deployed with the help of the Clemson University International Center for Automotive Research (CU-ICAR) in Greenville, SC in collaboration with our partners (PENN and OSU). The research and education activities undertaken provide numerous opportunities for inclusion and involvement of participants from various levels of education/backgrounds ranging from BS, MS to Ph.D. Over the years a number of industry days, code camps, and other outreach activities to middle/high school students were also conducted. This has led to a growing community of 500+ F1TENTH participants spanning 80+ universities spread across the world. The overall burgeoning ConnectedAutonomy capabilities and growing team-strength have also contributed to the development of several new research/education partnerships. The Web Portals (https://f1tenth.org; https://courses.f1tenth.org/; https://github.com/f1tenth; https://autodrive-ecosystem.github.io/) capture the most up-to-date information about various research, educational and outreach aspects of the project to the community at large.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2024
Modified by: Venkat N Krovi
